thread.title: Fishing report: Oct. 2 - News Sentinel
thread.title_full: Fishing report: Oct. 2 - News Sentinel Story

author: knoxnews.com
title: Fishing report: Oct. 2 - News Sentinel
text:
Cherokee
Full pool 1073 feet. The lake level is just over 1055 feet and falling, down almost 2 feet from two weeks ago. Water temperatures are in the mid to upper 70s. Smallmouth and Largemouth Bass: Improving. The bite is starting to pick up. The larger fish are 25-30 feet deep. Crank baits and jigs were popular as were swim baits and Texas rigs. Crappie: Fair. Minnows continue to catch fish 20-25 feet deep around wood during the day and under lights at night.
Douglas
Full pool 990 feet. Lake level is at 976 ¼ feet and falling, down 2 ¼ feet from two weeks ago. Water temperatures are in the mid to upper 70s. Largemouth and Smallmouth Bass: Good. Recent night tournaments are taking around 12 pounds to win while day events are taking 20 pounds to win. Bigger fish are being found 20-30 feet deep on the edges of humps and drop offs. Deep diving crank baits, swim baits, football head jigs, large spoons and Carolina or Texas rigs are finding fish. Line weight of 10 pound or less does make a difference in the number of bites produced on jigs. Crappie: Fair. Float and minnow rigs or just minnows are finding fish around submerged wood 20 feet deep.
Ft. Loudoun/Tellico
Full pool 813 feet. Lake level is at 812 ¼ feet, unchanged from last week. Water temperatures are in the low 80s. Smallmouth Bass: Fair. Jigs, medium running crank baits, swim baits and Carolina and Texas rigs remain popular. Largemouth Bass: Fair. Rocky points and wood are holding fish from 10-25 feet deep. Texas-rigged large worms, jigs, spoons, swim baits, spinner baits and crank baits are finding fish. Crappie: Fair. Fish are 15-25 feet deep. 1/8 ounce lead-head jigs tipped with minnows, small crank baits and inline spinners are catching fish. Brush piles, docks, house boats and marinas are holding fish.
Norris
Full pool is 1020 feet. Lake level is just over 1003 feet and falling, down almost 4 feet from two weeks ago. Water temperatures are in the upper 70s. Smallmouth Bass: Slow. Early and late in the day buzz baits and Zara-Spooks are producing a few catches. After dark spinner baits, rubber-skirted or hair jigs and Texas rigs are producing a few bites. Steeper, rocky banks and points are holding fish. Largemouth Bass: Fair. The best daytime bites are early in the morning and then again just prior to dusk. Spooks, buzz baits, Texas rigs with 8- to 12-inch worms and jigs are finding fish. Crappie: Fair. Fish are 15-30 feet deep. Brush piles, bridge pilings and bluff banks are holding fish. Tuffy minnows and mini-tube jigs remain popular. Striped Bass: Fair. Fish are 15-25 feet deep mid-channel and most are being caught on umbrella rigs. Walleye: Improving. The bite is picking up with spinner-worm rigs and trolled deep-diving Rebels or Thundersticks.
Melton Hill
Full pool 793 feet. Lake level is at 793 ¾ feet, unchanged from last week. Water temperatures range from the upper 50s to the mid 70s depending on the generation at Norris Dam and how far down the lake you are. Largemouth and Smallmouth Bass: Good. The smaller fish are more active but keeper fish are still rare. Swim baits, spinner baits, crank baits and jigs are finding fish during the day. At night spinner baits and Carolina- or Texas-rigged worms or Brush hogs in green-pumpkin and jigs are finding fish up to 25 feet deep. Musky: Slow. Submerged wood in deeper holes is holding fish as are some deeper main-lake rocky banks. Large stick baits, spinner baits and Texas-rigged worms are producing a few bites at night. Crappie: Fair. The bite is slow during the day but better at night under lights. Fish are 15-20 feet deep and close to the bottom or tight to cover. Minnows, tube jigs, Popeye Flies and Trout Magnets remain popular. Striped Bass: Slow. Early mornings breaking fish are beginning to be more active. Trolling live shad or umbrella rigs is finding fish.
Watts Bar
Full pool 741 feet. Lake level is just over 740 ½ feet, unchanged from last week. Water temperatures are near 80 degrees. Smallmouth and Largemouth Bass: Good. During the day swim baits, deep-diving crank baits, Carolina and Texas rigs with large worms, big spoons and hair jigs are finding fish 15-25 feet deep near channel ledges. Crappie: Fair. Creeks and bluff banks are holding fish in 15-25 feet of water on the bottom or tight to cover. Shady, deep water, rocky areas are good locations to fish. Blue, green, chartreuse or white jigs and minnows are catching fish.
Bill Hickey is a freelance contributor.
